title: Finish the Lyric
description: Can you complete these famous song lyrics from the golden age of music? Fill in the missing words from beloved hits of the 50s through the 80s!

questions.question: The Beatles, 1967: "All you need is ___"
questions.explanation: "All You Need Is Love" was released by The Beatles in 1967 and became an anthem of the Summer of Love.

questions.question: Bobby McFerrin, 1988: "Don't worry, be ___"
questions.explanation: "Don't Worry, Be Happy" by Bobby McFerrin was the first a cappella song to reach number one on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1988.

questions.question: Frank Sinatra, 1969: "I did it ___"
questions.explanation: "My Way" became Frank Sinatra's signature song. The English lyrics were written by Paul Anka, adapted from a French song.

questions.question: Queen, 1977: "We will, we will ___ you"
questions.explanation: "We Will Rock You" by Queen was written by Brian May and became one of the most recognizable stadium anthems in rock history.

questions.question: Louis Armstrong, 1967: "And I think to myself, what a wonderful ___"
questions.explanation: "What a Wonderful World" was recorded by Louis Armstrong in 1967. Though initially not a hit in the US, it became one of the most beloved songs of all time.

questions.question: The Supremes, 1966: "You can't hurry love, no, you'll just have to ___"
questions.explanation: "You Can't Hurry Love" by The Supremes reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1966. It was written by the legendary Motown team of Holland-Dozier-Holland.

questions.question: Simon & Garfunkel, 1964: "Hello darkness, my old ___"
questions.explanation: "The Sound of Silence" by Simon & Garfunkel was originally released in 1964 and became a massive hit when re-released with electric instruments in 1966.

questions.question: The Drifters, 1962: "Save the last ___ for me"
questions.explanation: "Save the Last Dance for Me" by The Drifters was actually released in 1960 and topped the charts. It was written by Doc Pomus and Mort Shuman.

questions.question: Otis Redding, 1968: "Sittin' on the dock of the ___"
questions.explanation: "(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay" was released posthumously in 1968 after Otis Redding's tragic death in a plane crash. It became the first posthumous number-one single in US chart history.

questions.question: Journey, 1981: "Don't stop ___"
questions.explanation: "Don't Stop Believin'" by Journey, released in 1981, has become one of the top-selling digital singles in history, experiencing a resurgence decades after its release.

questions.question: The Animals, 1964: "There is a house in New ___"
questions.explanation: "The House of the Rising Sun" by The Animals, about a place in New Orleans, became a number-one hit in 1964 and is considered one of the first folk-rock songs.

questions.question: Etta James, 1960: "At last, my love has come ___"
questions.explanation: "At Last" by Etta James was released in 1960 and has become one of the most iconic love songs in American music history, frequently played at weddings.

questions.question: The Righteous Brothers, 1964: "You've lost that ___ feelin'"
questions.explanation: "You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin'" was produced by Phil Spector and became one of the most-played songs on American radio in the 20th century.

questions.question: Bill Withers, 1972: "Lean on me, when you're not ___"
questions.explanation: "Lean on Me" by Bill Withers reached number one in 1972. Withers was inspired by his childhood in a West Virginia coal-mining town where neighbors helped each other.

questions.question: Ben E. King, 1961: "When the night has come, and the land is ___"
questions.explanation: "Stand by Me" by Ben E. King was released in 1961. The song was inspired by a gospel song and has been covered more than 400 times by various artists.
